citations.narrative:
Two events have occurred at the facility, resulting in two birds unable to be accounted for by the staff. The facility was
unable to locate one Red-winged blackbird from its aviary. Despite increased daily observations and the addition of
cameras within the habitat, the bird was declared missing/deceased on August 5, 2025. Employees were unable to
visualize this animal since July 18, 2025. Additionally, one Wood thrush was noted missing from its habitat on September
12th, 2025. The staff identified an approximate 4 x 4 inch round hole in the front corner of the habitat that was not present
the night before. While the facility’s investigation of both events showed no evidence of feather loss, predation, or pest
activity, the staff increased surveillance, observations, and housekeeping measures immediately following each event.
Compromised housing enclosures can provide a route of escape, entrapment, or injury to the animals contained therein.
These animals are more vulnerable to harm and further injury when they are not safely contained or cannot be accounted
for. The facility must ensure that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the
birds, and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds housed within.
Corrective actions were taken by the facility following these occurrences.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Two events have occurred at the facility, resulting in two birds unable to be accounted for by the staff. The facility was 
unable to locate one Red-winged blackbird from its aviary. Despite increased daily observations and the addition of 
cameras within the habitat, the bird was declared missing/deceased on August 5, 2025. Employees were unable to 
visualize this animal since July 18, 2025. Additionally, one Wood thrush was noted missing from its habitat on September 
12th, 2025. The staff identified an approximate 4 x 4 inch round hole in the front corner of the habitat that was not present 
the night before. While the facility’s investigation of both events showed no evidence of feather loss, predation, or pest 
activity, the staff increased surveillance, observations, and housekeeping measures immediately following each event. 
 
Compromised housing enclosures can provide a route of escape, entrapment, or injury to the animals contained therein. 
These animals are more vulnerable to harm and further injury when they are not safely contained or cannot be accounted 
for. The facility must ensure that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the 
birds, and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds housed within.  
 
Corrective actions were taken by the facility following these occurrences. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
